Award.AwardTitle: Air chemistry Research In Asia (ARIAs): Aerosol and Trace Gas Emissions and Transformations over the North China Plain
Award.AbstractNarration:
Emissions, transport and transformations of aerosols and trace gases from Asia increasingly impact local, regional and even global environments. The chemical and physical mechanisms by which atmospheric processes change the properties and concentrations of trace gases and aerosols remain challenging questions in tropospheric chemistry research.

Through partnerships with Peking University, Beijing Normal University, and the Hebei provincial weather service, this collaborative study, Air Chemistry Research In Asia (ARIAs) will facilitate concurrent aircraft and ground measurements, aerosol optical properties and trace gas composition over the North China Plain (NCP). Ultimately, the results from this project will improve theory and predictive capability of environmental models, used to develop mitigation strategies for air pollution from the Asian continent and to better understand the fate of short-lived climate forcers such as ozone and aerosols in these high population, high emission environments.

The project will also serve to further educate a research associate, and graduate and undergraduate students and, through its outreach component, K-12 students. The project will also renew collaborations with leading Chinese research groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over Hebei province, China, one of the most heavily polluted regions of the world, we collected a rich data set of trace gas concentrations and aerosol properties in May and June 2016.  These observations help understand the origins of and solutions to local air pollution and climate problems and their l impacts on the Earth as a whole. 

We have published a paper based on aircraft and satellite observations indicating that CO concentrations are underpredicted by MOPITT [Tang et al., 2020], showing the difficulty of detecting CO near the surface in regions of heavy aerosol loading. We characterized source regions over Korea by using observed CO/CO2 ratios to show when the influence of Chinese emissions was measurable [Halliday et al., 2020]. The measured SO2 profiles were used to evaluate and calibrate remotely sensed observations that indicate that India has overtaken China as the world?s largest source of sulfur to the atmosphere [C Li et al., 2017]. A paper in ACP provides insight into the planetary boundary layer (PBL) production of ozone over the North China Plain; the O3 sensitivity regime is determined to be NOx-limited throughout the PBL, while more VOC-limited at low altitudes near urban centers, demonstrating that both VOCs and NOx need further control to reduce aloft O3 over Hebei now out of discussion and in print [Benish et al., 2020]. In a joint paper with NCAR [Gaubert et al., 2020] we used ARIAs observations to correct model bias and improve simulation of oxidants.  Several presentations were made at national and international meetings.  An Eos article summarizes the impact of aerosols on clouds, precipitation, and climate over China [Z Q Li, 2020]. We found evidence of new CFC production in China, compared the TO-15 to NOAA?s calibration scale, and submitted a publication to JGR [Benish et al., 2021].

Earlier papers [F Wang et al., 2018; Y Wang et al., 2019] examine trace gases and aerosols over Hebei.  We thoroughly characterized for the first time the regional variability of aerosol optical profiles scattering and backscattering, absorption, extinction, single scattering albedo (SSA), and the ?ngstr?m exponent (α) over the North China Plain. The SSA at 550 nm showed a regional mean value of 0.85?0.02 with moderate to strong absorption and α ranged from 0.49 to 2.53 (median 1.53) indicating both mineral dust and accumulation mode aerosols.  Back-trajectory analysis shows that clean air masses generally originated from the distant north-western part of China while most of the polluted air masses were from heavily industrialized interior and coastal areas.  A DOAS paper [Y Wang et al., 2019] explains profiles of trace gases in terms of source regions and meteorology.

Two Ph.D. dissertations were written using the ARIAs data, Dr. Sarah E. Benish in Atmospheric and Oceanic Science  now employed at EPA and Dr. Courtney D. Grimes in Chemistry now employed at the DOEE of Washington, DC.
